posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content: Heya, plz don't call me a stalker, but I seriously don't understand what those many levels of Bard are giving you so late in the build. You take the 6th Bard level at 28, then in your thirties you start taking Bard to get to 12, where your spells aren't all that better, your song is, but look at what it's costing you, and you do get more skill points. If you want more skills, I'd go Bard 16 at least, if you want more feats, Fighter 26 Bard 4 is good if you delay RDD to epics. It's not that it's a bad build, but IMO not optimized.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Delaying RDD to epic would be optimal only if the build was born at level 40, but I would play this build from level 1 through about level 36 or 37 in the Aielund Saga, so I want some of that STR boost as early as possible. I think I have struck a good balance between feats and skills for my needs. I would have to give up some of one to get more of the other. The Aielund Saga is full of really cool weapons, and I want to be free to use any weapon I come across.

I thought to myself "How can I be effective without Weapon Focus, Weapon Spec, etc?" The answer I came up with was extra STR from RDD levels.

posts.author: Demos
posts.content:
Personally, I think the point you're missing about having a universal warrior is that focusing/specializing in a certain weapon doesn't mean you can't be good at other weapons. With your AB at 44, you would be at 47 with a focused weapon, and you have the feats available to do it.

I would drop Dodge, Mobility, Spring Attack and Great Cleave. The first 3 are good if you're going for Whirlwind Attack or Weapon Master. You're not and your Tumble score is high enough to avoid AoE's. Whirlwind Attack was discussed on the older version of this thread, so that is an option (drop Great Cleave for it). I think Great Cleave is fairly useless unless you're going for Dev Crit. If you drop those 4 feats, here are some options:

Option 1: Take Weapon Focus, Weapon Spec, Improved Critical and Expertise (move it from Epic) and Epic Weapon Focus. AB stays at 44 for all weapons and 47 for your focused one.
Option 2: Take Knockdown, Improved Knockdown (or Called Shot), Disarm, Improved Disarm. AB stays at 44 for all weapons but now opens up a lot more combat maneuvers.
Option 3: Drop Great Cleave for Whirlwind Attack (and keep Dodge, Mobility, and Spring Attack). For mobs you could kill in 1 hit, Whirlwind Attack will have the same effect. It will also hit people you can't target but are in melee range (Invisible, Sanctuary, Hidden)

I would drop Dodge, Mobility, Spring Attack and Great Cleave. The first 3 are good if you're going for Whirlwind Attack or Weapon Master. You're not and your Tumble score is high enough to avoid AoE's.
Dodge adds +1 AC vs current target no matter AoOs and Mobility adds +4 dodge AC not counting towards the +20 cap vs all AoOs not just those from moving in combat. The only thing a high enough tumble eventually makes redundant is Spring Attack. In fact Dodge and Mobility are good feat choices if one has feats to spare, no matter SD or WM.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Option 2: Whenever I have Knockdown, I find myself never using it, so it is wasted. This makes me prefer passive feats.
Mate, this is a very good opportunity for you to become a better player. I don't know whether you'll ever leave the Aielund Saga and start playing online, but as a general rule, you become a better player when you migrate to online play. If you play Aielund with a really good build, like for example my Magical Master, you can LITERALLY just click on attack and then go for a cup of coffee and when you come back, everything will be dead. When you play without pause, for starters, and in a place where you can be very dead in just a couple of seconds, you begin to value and appreciate more the usefulness of stuff like Knockdown. The thing is that in certain places, if you don't KD a monster, you'll DIE to it, be it by a medusa petrifying gaze, an instant death spell or petrification spell, an Implosion spell cast by a boss, etc... I know Aielund, I love it, but the items are a bit on the overpowered side. Not enhancement-wise, but immunity-wise, which is kinda bad because lots of immunities de-value a lot of the class features, which causes players to do exactly what you just mentioned: not using stuff that is very good. I know that in the very beginning of act 2 you can already get an item called Cowl of Warding, which makes you immune to fear and mind affecting spells. That may lead to the very wrong impression that potions of Clarity are useless, but I ALWAYS carry a couple of stacks of them in my meleers, because I know I won't succeed on a Will save EVER in a balanced environment.

Just food for thought. Later on, if you do decide to follow my advice, you`ll look back and see what now is hidden to you. If you keep learning, in 3 years try playing the Aielund saga again and you`ll see exactly what I mean!

Take it EZ!

posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
NwnwhiteBoy wrote:Off topic I know, sorry. But
Maximillian Kane wrote:Probably the fact that it nerfed Epic Dodge and Dragon shape?
How does it nerf them? just curious.
Epic Dodge now requires 30 tumble ranks while before 1.69 a single rank was sufficient: this means that now ED cannot be acquired before lvl 30, while before one could get it as soon as lvl 21.

Dragon shape now requires 18+ druid levels, while before 14 lvls were enough: this means many nice builds are no longer possible.

Actually, WW is a matter of timing. If you attempt to trigger another WW before the last one ends, it will lock up the toon. Very inconvenient when it happens on a PW but many servers have provided a fix within their own customizations.

Yes, it's still a bug but you can address almost all of these issues by DLing a comprehensive community fix (Kail may want to comment on the reliability of the beta here).

The bottom line is: Install v1.69.

It makes no sense to post build designs based on random patch versions. The scope of pre-v1.69 use is just too limiting to be of any significant value to the general building community. Consider v1.69 as the even playing field. It's the point where all content has grown from and even with the few remaining bugs and unbalances (many prefer 3.5 rules) it still fixes more than it harms. Besides, if you use Kamiryn's CBC to generate a build, IT is based on v1.69.

My two centavos for what it's worth, amigo.

posts.author: WhiZard
posts.content:
HipMaestro wrote:
Actually, WW is a matter of timing. If you attempt to trigger another WW before the last one ends, it will lock up the toon. Very inconvenient when it happens on a PW but many servers have provided a fix within their own customizations.
Actually whirlwind attack stacking puts an untargeted attack action in between the whirlwind actions. If you use windows you can deselect the attack action in the middle (choosing the queue options at the top left) and thus don't have to worry about even an instance of flatfootedness.

EDIT: Also, if you use whirlwind attack frequently, you might want to take the often shunned feat of dirty fighting. For whirlwind attack you keep all blows and add the dirty fighting bonus to each one.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Unfortunately, I am going to bore you with statistics again in order to explain, Stagmeister.

This is the Armor check penalty.  Don't confuse it with the Maximum Dexterity Bonus:

Skill penalty, Full plate: -8 Tumble
Skill penalty, Tower shield: -10 Tumble
Net skill needed to avoid all AoOs while moving: Tumble 14

Therefore, all you need to tumble through combat like a naked monkey (even wearing the heaviest gear) is 18 + 14 = 32.  

So, until you can dump the next pile of Tumble points, you may be better off using lighter armor/shield.  The important thing is to keep checking your skill screen for the net Tumble value.  As long as it remains at least 14, you are a master of the skill.  By the time the toon reaches the final AC dump, heavy gear is no longer an issue. Also, gear weight will not effect your reflexes either... for some reason only the game designers understand, because I certainly don't.  Wear a suit of armor and try to limbo, then report your opinion.

posts.author: Valerfor

@Empyre65
It's pretty simple: move one of your early bard levels to a general feat level & you can take curse song there. Or, you could do this instead: Replace Dodge with Toughness => Take Curse Song at 18th level & then replace Great Cleave with Dodge. There are many other ways to do this but this should suffice.
